THE WILSON CONTEST
The essay contest sponsored by the Woodrow Wilson Foundation should hold more interest for Hopkins men than perhaps any
other students in the country. In this season of pre-exam anxiety
and worrying over next year's schedules, little thought is given to
other matters, but at any Commemoration Exercise, Class Day,
or similar function, some speaker is almost sure to allude with
pride to the notables who have studied or lectured at Johns Hopkins. Woodrow-Wilson is usually the first to be mentioned.
President Wilson's memory has been dealt with in a number
of different ways in University courses. One of the history professors speaks of him as a political idealist who might have given
the world some sort of a panacea in the League of Nations. Time
only will tell, he says. Many of the students of political science
receive a more personal view of the former President.
The contest should be a peculiarly fitting one to students of
this University. It is not particularly likely that a Hopkins man
should be fortunate enough to win the twenty-five thousand dollar
prize, but stranger things than that have happened.. Time only
will tell.

OUR PERENNIAL TRAFFIC PROBLEM
Mr. Gaither is not the only one who has his traffic worries.
He may have to spend sleepless nights wondering where to put his
next automatic signal, but he does not have to bother about how
automobilists drive over his grass. Finally, after much gnashing
of teeth, the Superintendent of the Grounds (we suppose he was
responsible) at the University seems to have accepted the ruining
of the grass behind the Civil Engineering Building as a fait accompli, and tacitly indicated his willingness to allow cars to park
there by the position of the nice new green stakes he has had
,erected. Perhaps some day, we shall have a vast underground
-parking arena so that everyone can be happy!

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS LETTER. MAY 20, 1927

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS
A number of rare Spanish and
American coins of the early eighteenth century have recently been
unearthed at West Virginia University. Numerous theories have
been advanced as to their probable
origin. That which has been generally accepted is, that they wert
a portion of the loot of the early
Indian raids and were buried there
by them.
* * *
To .continue in the line of "buried treasure," an interesting assemblage of Mid-Victorian china plate
was recently discovered by workmen at Harvard University. The
pieces have been received with en• thusiasm and their pattern • will undoubtedly be used in an attempt to
perpetuate the memorie-s of all that
used to be at fair Harvard.
• Another ultra mcidern or ultra
antiquarian (take your choice) college is being established .at Carbondale, Ill. In accordance with its decrees, fraternities, dancing, athletics, and student governmeni are barred; while the uses of the filthy
weed and strong waters are. banned.
Looks like there is something worse
than the "New Plan" after all.
. * * *
The well-known weakness of the
opposite sex in regard to confectionery has again come to the fore
—this time at Vassar College, where
it has confounded proponents of
the, until •then successful, Honor
System. The girls had been on their
honor to deposit sufficient money in
a box to pay for their purchases of
candy. Recently, however, steady
-Mk-Cy-of "alwat -eighr-dollars per
day have compelled the proprietOrs
to keep their sweets under personal
supervision.
*

*

Approximately one-sixth of the
fair coeds in the seventeen sororities
at Ohio State University are engaged or married, according to • a
recently completed survey. The
young ladies seem to take it more
seriously than their boy friends,
however, as only twelve rings are
reported out of the total assemblage
of 119 girls.
*

•

▪

The Cunard liner S. S. Aurania
is now being converted into what
will soon be the second Floating
University. September 21. has been
set as the sailing date and it is estimated that five hundred students
will be registered by that time. Six
months will be spent on the high
seas, and two months in the always
interesting tours. The officials of
the cruise tell us that "the cruise
just ended was coeducational''—
that we already know, but when
they state that "that is the only way
in which the ideals we have in mind
can be beneficially carried out," we
are nonplussed. What are their
ideals and how do they define beneficially?

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS LETTER MAY 20, 1927

4

SPEAKING
OF

SPORTS
Rutgers did Hopkins a great
favor Saturday when they defeated
Syracuse by the score of 6-5. This
was the first defeat in intercollegiate
competition, that the Orange has
suffered in the past three years.
And then this game was lost only
after the bitterest kind of a struggle, Syracuse leading 3-2 at half
time. But the New Brunswick stickwielders came back in the second
period and a belated rally netted
two goals and the victory.
* * *
It is reported that the Orange, fig
uring on an easy game, left three
first string defense players back at
Syracuse. This overconfidepce cost
the New Yorkers their chances for
consideration in the awarding of
this season's National Championship and a possible opportunity to
represent the United States in the
1928 Olympic games.
• Should Hopkins defeat"Maryland
tomorrow and should Dr. Goodnow
remain in Europe until next year, he
might be very glad the New Plan
did not go into effect last fall.
* * *
Harvard had a banner day Saturday, the track team defeating
Dartmouth and the baseball aggregation conquering the Williams nine.
There has been a great ballyhoo
raised by the people of Cambridge
this spring over the Crimson nine.
Led by "Izzy" Zarakov, the only
Jewish boy to ever captain a Harvard athletic team, the baseball organization has made an enviable record this season and should Yale be
beaten, which looms as a gigantic
undertaking, the Crimson should be
looked over closely when the time
comes to award the championship.
By defeating Dartmouth, the
Cambrige runners demonstrated
that they have one of the best teams
in the country. Due to the excellent record made by the Crimson
team, it is expected that they will
furnish California'and Stanford the
keenest opposition among the Eastern colleges in the I. C. A. A. A. A.
games.
* * *
Gold charms were awarded to the
members of the varsity swimming
team at Williams last week because
of the excellent showing made by
the mermen during the past season.
We wonder what kinds of charms
•were given. Gold swimming pools
or gold tank suits maybe, but it
would be hard to imagine one of
them being worn on a watch chain.

SOPIIS TO. ELECT
COUNCIL MEMBER
U.
H. Allen, • P. Frisch,
Gibbs, W. B. Hammond,, G.
Hill and D. Hiss were nominated for junior delegates to
next year's Student Council at
a meeting held by the sophomore class Tuesday.
The election of these men
will take place next Thursday
at 11:20 in the Civil Engineering Hall when two representatives are to be selected.
• According to Philip Ness,
.president of the sophomores,
all members of the class are
expected to attend Thursday's
meeting.

Dr. Edmunds To Speak
At Haverford College
Dr. Charles Keyser Edmunds,
former provost of Johns Hopkins
University, and now the American
Director of Canton Christian College (Lignan University), will deliver the first lecture under the William Penn Foundation for a course
in Political Science and International Relations, at Haverford College on Monday evening, May 23.
His subject will be the background
of the present Chinese situation.
The funds of this foundation will
be used for occasional lectures until
its entire quota of $120,000 has been
collected. Approximately $70,000
has been collected to date, and half
of this has been invested, the interest of which is being used for the
lectures.
Dr. Edmunds was a member of
the 'commission which sailed to Canton, China, last December. He was
president of Johns Hopkins University from 1907 to 1-924, when he
was made provost and alumni director.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 20, 1927

6
INTERFRATERNITY BOARD
ADOPTS RUSHING
AGREEMENT
Lengthening of Season and Change in
"Open House" Rules Are
Principal Revisions

Reaching an accord after over two
months of discussion the Interfraternity Board adopted a rushing
agreement for the coming season at
its regular meeting on Monday.
Many different plans had been considered ranging from "cut-throat"
rushing immediately after registration, to deferred rushing to start in
February.
The plan which was finally adopted provides for a rushing season of
approximately six weeks duration,
with a period of thirteen days of
"open house" included in this space
of time. Unlike the "open house"
season of this year, the propose!
season will allow each fraternity
only one day of "open house," but
on that day this fraternity will
have priority rights on any freshman on the campus. Thus, every
freshman will have the opportunity
to visit every fraternity house on
the campus, and not have his "open
house" dates conflict as was the case
so many times this year.

NOW OWN—

"What you going to do this summer, Jim?" is a question that one
hears asked frequently around the
Hopkins campus this time of the
year. Jim may or may not have his
job already "fixed," but at any rate
he is seriously planning to get one
and make some money during his
summer vacation.
"Jim's" job may be almost anything—the work done in the summer by college students is indeed
amazing in its variety—from hodcarrying to bell-hopping on ocean
liners, and to various types of selling or office work. But the real
reason back of all this work is to
make money.
Now, you yourself are "Jim",
and you are going to make some
money this summer. But—and this
is important—what are you going
to do with it? The answer is easy
—put some of it in a bank and save
it, for the approaching college year
will bring with it all sorts of financial problems which a bank account
alone can solve.

THE WILSON CONTEST
The essay contest sponsored by the Woodrow Wilson Foundation should hold more interest for Hopkins men than perhaps any
other students in the country. In this season of pre-exam anxiety
and worrying over next year's schedules, little thought is given to
other matters, but at any Commemoration Exercise, Class Day,
or similar function, some speaker is almost sure to allude with
pride to the notables who have studied or lectured at Johns Hopkins. Woodrow-Wilson is usually the first to be mentioned.
President Wilson's memory has been dealt with in a number
of different ways in University courses. One of the history professors speaks of him as a political idealist who might have given
the world some sort of a panacea in the League of Nations. Time
only will tell, he says. Many of the students of political science
receive a more personal view of the former President.
The contest should be a peculiarly fitting one to students of
this University. It is not particularly likely that a Hopkins man
should be fortunate enough to win the twenty-five thousand dollar
prize, but stranger things than that have happened.. Time only
will tell.

OUR PERENNIAL TRAFFIC PROBLEM
Mr. Gaither is not the only one who has his traffic worries.
He may have to spend sleepless nights wondering where to put his
next automatic signal, but he does not have to bother about how
automobilists drive over his grass. Finally, after much gnashing
of teeth, the Superintendent of the Grounds (we suppose he was
responsible) at the University seems to have accepted the ruining
of the grass behind the Civil Engineering Building as a fait accompli, and tacitly indicated his willingness to allow cars to park
there by the position of the nice new green stakes he has had
,erected. Perhaps some day, we shall have a vast underground
-parking arena so that everyone can be happy!

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS LETTER. MAY 20, 1927

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS
A number of rare Spanish and
American coins of the early eighteenth century have recently been
unearthed at West Virginia University. Numerous theories have
been advanced as to their probable
origin. That which has been generally accepted is, that they wert
a portion of the loot of the early
Indian raids and were buried there
by them.
* * *
To .continue in the line of "buried treasure," an interesting assemblage of Mid-Victorian china plate
was recently discovered by workmen at Harvard University. The
pieces have been received with en• thusiasm and their pattern • will undoubtedly be used in an attempt to
perpetuate the memorie-s of all that
used to be at fair Harvard.
• Another ultra mcidern or ultra
antiquarian (take your choice) college is being established .at Carbondale, Ill. In accordance with its decrees, fraternities, dancing, athletics, and student governmeni are barred; while the uses of the filthy
weed and strong waters are. banned.
Looks like there is something worse
than the "New Plan" after all.
. * * *
The well-known weakness of the
opposite sex in regard to confectionery has again come to the fore
—this time at Vassar College, where
it has confounded proponents of
the, until •then successful, Honor
System. The girls had been on their
honor to deposit sufficient money in
a box to pay for their purchases of
candy. Recently, however, steady
-Mk-Cy-of "alwat -eighr-dollars per
day have compelled the proprietOrs
to keep their sweets under personal
supervision.
*

*

Approximately one-sixth of the
fair coeds in the seventeen sororities
at Ohio State University are engaged or married, according to • a
recently completed survey. The
young ladies seem to take it more
seriously than their boy friends,
however, as only twelve rings are
reported out of the total assemblage
of 119 girls.
*

•

▪

*

*

The Cunard liner S. S. Aurania
is now being converted into what
will soon be the second Floating
University. September 21. has been
set as the sailing date and it is estimated that five hundred students
will be registered by that time. Six
months will be spent on the high
seas, and two months in the always
interesting tours. The officials of
the cruise tell us that "the cruise
just ended was coeducational''—
that we already know, but when
they state that "that is the only way
in which the ideals we have in mind
can be beneficially carried out," we
are nonplussed. What are their
ideals and how do they define beneficially?

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS LETTER MAY 20, 1927

4

SPEAKING
OF

SPORTS
Rutgers did Hopkins a great
favor Saturday when they defeated
Syracuse by the score of 6-5. This
was the first defeat in intercollegiate
competition, that the Orange has
suffered in the past three years.
And then this game was lost only
after the bitterest kind of a struggle, Syracuse leading 3-2 at half
time. But the New Brunswick stickwielders came back in the second
period and a belated rally netted
two goals and the victory.
* * *
It is reported that the Orange, fig
uring on an easy game, left three
first string defense players back at
Syracuse. This overconfidepce cost
the New Yorkers their chances for
consideration in the awarding of
this season's National Championship and a possible opportunity to
represent the United States in the
1928 Olympic games.
• Should Hopkins defeat"Maryland
tomorrow and should Dr. Goodnow
remain in Europe until next year, he
might be very glad the New Plan
did not go into effect last fall.
* * *
Harvard had a banner day Saturday, the track team defeating
Dartmouth and the baseball aggregation conquering the Williams nine.
There has been a great ballyhoo
raised by the people of Cambridge
this spring over the Crimson nine.
Led by "Izzy" Zarakov, the only
Jewish boy to ever captain a Harvard athletic team, the baseball organization has made an enviable record this season and should Yale be
beaten, which looms as a gigantic
undertaking, the Crimson should be
looked over closely when the time
comes to award the championship.
By defeating Dartmouth, the
Cambrige runners demonstrated
that they have one of the best teams
in the country. Due to the excellent record made by the Crimson
team, it is expected that they will
furnish California'and Stanford the
keenest opposition among the Eastern colleges in the I. C. A. A. A. A.
games.
* * *
Gold charms were awarded to the
members of the varsity swimming
team at Williams last week because
of the excellent showing made by
the mermen during the past season.
We wonder what kinds of charms
•were given. Gold swimming pools
or gold tank suits maybe, but it
would be hard to imagine one of
them being worn on a watch chain.

The election of these men
will take place next Thursday

• According to Philip Ness,
.president of the sophomores,
all members of the class are
expected to attend Thursday's
meeting.

Dr. Edmunds To Speak
At Haverford College
Dr. Charles Keyser Edmunds,
former provost of Johns Hopkins
University, and now the American
Director of Canton Christian College (Lignan University), will deliver the first lecture under the William Penn Foundation for a course
in Political Science and International Relations, at Haverford College on Monday evening, May 23.
His subject will be the background
of the present Chinese situation.
The funds of this foundation will
be used for occasional lectures until
its entire quota of $120,000 has been
collected. Approximately $70,000
has been collected to date, and half
of this has been invested, the interest of which is being used for the
lectures.
Dr. Edmunds was a member of
the 'commission which sailed to Canton, China, last December. He was
president of Johns Hopkins University from 1907 to 1-924, when he
was made provost and alumni director.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 20, 1927

6
INTERFRATERNITY BOARD
ADOPTS RUSHING
AGREEMENT
Lengthening of Season and Change in
"Open House" Rules Are
Principal Revisions

Reaching an accord after over two
months of discussion the Interfraternity Board adopted a rushing
agreement for the coming season at
its regular meeting on Monday.
Many different plans had been considered ranging from "cut-throat"
rushing immediately after registration, to deferred rushing to start in
February.
The plan which was finally adopted provides for a rushing season of
approximately six weeks duration,
with a period of thirteen days of
"open house" included in this space
of time. Unlike the "open house"
season of this year, the propose!
season will allow each fraternity
only one day of "open house," but
on that day this fraternity will
have priority rights on any freshman on the campus. Thus, every
freshman will have the opportunity
to visit every fraternity house on
the campus, and not have his "open
house" dates conflict as was the case
so many times this year.

NOW OWN—

"What you going to do this summer, Jim?" is a question that one
hears asked frequently around the
Hopkins campus this time of the
year. Jim may or may not have his
job already "fixed," but at any rate
he is seriously planning to get one
and make some money during his
summer vacation.
"Jim's" job may be almost anything—the work done in the summer by college students is indeed
amazing in its variety—from hodcarrying to bell-hopping on ocean
liners, and to various types of selling or office work. But the real
reason back of all this work is to
make money.
Now, you yourself are "Jim",
and you are going to make some
money this summer. But—and this
is important—what are you going
to do with it? The answer is easy
—put some of it in a bank and save
it, for the approaching college year
will bring with it all sorts of financial problems which a bank account
alone can solve.
